# column_is_within_n_std { #pelage.column_is_within_n_std }

```python
column_is_within_n_std(data, items, *args)
```

Function asserting values are within a given STD range, thus ensuring the absence
of outliers.

## Parameters {.doc-section .doc-section-parameters}

<code><span class="parameter-name">data</span><span class="parameter-annotation-sep">:</span> <span class="parameter-annotation">[PolarsLazyOrDataFrame](`pelage.types.PolarsLazyOrDataFrame`)</span></code>

:   Polars DataFrame or LazyFrame containing data to check.

<code><span class="parameter-name">items</span><span class="parameter-annotation-sep">:</span> <span class="parameter-annotation">[Tuple](`typing.Tuple`)\[[PolarsColumnType](`pelage.types.PolarsColumnType`), [int](`int`)\]</span></code>

:   A column name / column type with the number of STD authorized for the values
    within. Must be of the following form: `(col_name, n_std)`

## Returns {.doc-section .doc-section-returns}

| Name   | Type                                                          | Description                                                      |
|--------|---------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
|        | [PolarsLazyOrDataFrame](`pelage.types.PolarsLazyOrDataFrame`) | The original polars DataFrame or LazyFrame when the check passes |

## Examples {.doc-section .doc-section-examples}

```python
>>> import polars as pl
>>> import pelage as plg
>>> df = pl.DataFrame(
...     {
...         "a": list(range(0, 11)),
...         "b": list(range(0, 11)),
...         "c": list(range(0, 10)) + [5000],
...     }
... )
>>> df.pipe(plg.column_is_within_n_std, ("a", 2), ("b", 3))
```
